Transcription for 1764991

Recording made by Glenys James in Ponoka, Alberta on the 3rd of July 1974 with several
members of the Welsh settlement. The interviews are in English and in Welsh, starting in English
with Griffith Jones, followed by a group interview with Hugh Roberts, Mrs Annie Roberts, Kelt
Hughes, Evan Thomas, Garonwy Davies and Yorwith Davies.
Mr Griffith Jones, you were born in Canada of Welsh parents.
Since we did not speak Welsh in the home, I didn't learn Welsh when I should have and I
regret it since. However, I do like to hear the Welsh and one of the biggest thrills I had in
visiting Wales this summer was to hear the little children speak it. It sounded good. Dad
came from Wales, Tre Gyrfaen, first in 1891 and after several trips back came out again in 1910
and settled in the Wood River District. Mother is of Welsh, was of Welsh parents and she came from
the United States to Canada in 1902 and they were married in 1911. There were four of us that were
born to them and probably I speak as good of Welsh as any of them which isn't very good.
Now your father was well known in the area here for his Welsh writing of England Neon both Welsh
and English. He was well known all over North America in fact because he contributed to the
Welsh papers and he competed in all the Welsh Estadwods that he could with his England Neon
and he won many prizes with them. Can you recall any of these England Neon that he wrote? I could
say one in English. As you know the England must have consonants that harmonize and one that he
won a prize on in English was Lindy how well he landed in Paris though peril confronted. Gritty
Yank with great head away he went undaunted. I wish I could say some of them in the Welsh
because they sounded very musical even to my Canadian ears. When you visited Wales this year
for the first time what else impressed you about Wales and the Welsh way of life? We had the good
fortune to attend the command begone in Rosanus Grigogh and this gave us one of our biggest thrills
and also to see the old churches and houses where dad lived where he went to church and some of the
farms that he trampled over looking after his Welsh sheep. We met many of my cousins too whom
I had never seen and one thing that really impressed me especially in the Kiriogh Valley
was the way everyone spoke Welsh and they would rather speak Welsh than English. Did you have a
chance to practice your Welsh there? Oh yes I had many opportunities and we are looking forward to
going back again as soon as possible possibly two years. Wednesday the 3rd of July in Ponoka.
Now Mr. Hugh Roberts, do you remember the story of the chapel in Wood River when it started?
Yes, the chapel started in 1914. The Welsh church was open in Ponoka beyond the chapel in Wood River.
delicious clouds
They benefited all form of food, of water but the Welsh

Mrs. Hughes and Mrs. Thomas Jones
Mrs. Hughes and Mrs. Thomas Jones
came from Wales on the same boat
and also on the same train.

she had put, she carried a picture of John Bunyan with her,

Will you reach me John Bunyan, please?

When we first came into the district here,
there was four Hugh Joneses.
One we called Hugh D.,
the other Hugh T.,
the other Hugh H., and the other Hugh W.
We never mentioned the Joneses,
there were so many Joneses in the district.
The same thing pretty well applied to the William Joneses.
We had William Reese Jones, we had William Jones,
we had William T. Jones,
and we called them Will T., Will Reese, and William Jones.
We had to have a little respect for him because he was the older.
You didn't give them any nicknames?
No, not really, just initials.
We just used initials.
Could you tell me some of the reasons why the Welsh people came to this area?
Well, I think mainly they came because of cheap land.
We could get homesteads there.
You paid $10 for a quarter section,
and you had to farm it.
You had to live on it for three years.
You had to produce it,
you had to live on it for three years,
you had to prove up on it.
You had to cultivate 30 acres
and put $500 worth of improvements on it before you could get title.
Another reason was that a lot of them had lived in the dry areas
of southern Alberta
and also many different parts of the United States.
This was considered a wet area,
lots of timber, lots of water,
I don't know, other reasons, no doubt.
Then after one Welsh family had came here,
naturally it attracted others.
Their relatives and friends came here.
That's about all I think.
Who would you say was the first Welsh person to come to the area?
Well, I think mainly the people who came to the area
were the first people who came to the area.
They were the first people who came to the area.
Well, I think maybe Karl Morris might have been one of the very first ones.
And Reverend D.L. Hughes,
a Welsh minister, came here in the very early days.
When would that be?
About 1900 I would think.
Most people seemed like,
what we call the early settlers,
seemed to settle in this area around 1900.
And they were the first people to come to the area.
And what we call the early settlers seemed to settle in this area around the turn of the century.

But when I was a little boy, I went to Scotland.
In the school, around there.
And then in the chapel, then.
And we were teaching at the road mam.
And Tada and Mamma were teaching us in the school.
And when we were growing up, we went to watch classes.
And when we were in the 16th or 17th grade, we were in the adult class.
And we were teaching Welsh in the school.
And we had a Bible that was in Welsh, that was in English.
And we had a lot of fun trying to get different interpretations of the Bible in Welsh and the Bible in Welsh.
At the beginning of the school, the magic school, we couldn't speak Welsh.
We couldn't speak English, we could only speak Welsh.
And what we were teaching was through the school.
And we were taught all three classes when we were little.
The first year in the magic school.
And the magic school was around the whole of the children of Wales.
Some of the different languages there, but Welsh was the most.
It was magic for a couple of years.
I have a lot of friends who went to school and went to school in the same school as me.
Some of them were older.
And the school was very different from the rest of the children.
But talking about the school.
We had a school here in the early 1900s to before 1910.
And carried on for several years.
Then it carried on until about 1925 or somewhere in that neighborhood.
And then for a while we didn't have Stelwood again until the 1930s, the end of the 1930s.
And then they petered out.
And after about a lapse of 10, 15 years, we, descendants of the Welsh in Woodriver,
again started up the Stelwood, which is now called the Woodriver Festival.
And we are carrying on to this day, which is an annual event.
During the first festivals when I was a child, it consisted of music, elocution,
handiworks, such as making halters of things, cooking, and writing limericks.
These were competitive festivals.
And a lot of the singing was competitive.
Classes were old and young, even for the ones over 50.
Choirs were quite prominent.
And at that time, nearly all the Welsh people could sing that were here.
There were several quartets in one competition, and it was quite competitive.
And some of the choirs that were in this community were led by some of the Welsh people that came over from Wales.
And I think the tradition is still carrying on.
The Welsh people are still able to sing, and the Welsh songs are quite close to the heart
of most of the young people in the district at the present time.
